{"comments": {"id": 28218, "count": 47, "talk_id": 22704}, "threadId": 28218, "requested_language_english_name": "English", "current_talk": "22704", "description": "If we want sustainable, long-term security to be the norm in the world, it's time to radically rethink how we can achieve it, says TED Fellow and conflict researcher Benedetta Berti. In an eye-opening talk, Berti explains how building a safer world has a lot less to do with crushing enemies on the battlefield and a lot more to do with protecting civilians -- no matter where they're from or where they live.", "event": "TED2018", "language": "en", "language_swap": false, "name": "Benedetta Berti: Did the global response to 9/11 make us safer?", "slug": "benedetta_berti_did_the_global_response_to_9_11_make_us_safer", "series_slug": null, "speakers": [{"id": "2487", "slug": "benedetta_berti", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Benedetta", "lastname": "Berti", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Conflict and security researcher", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/c6f49d58aadddc8c43cb498b2d77d14c30e519a4_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "", "whotheyare": "Benedetta Berti studies how conflicts impact civilians.", "whylisten": "

Benedetta Berti is an expert on the role of armed groups and the future of armed conflict, especially in the Middle East. She has spent over a decade researching non-state armed groups, from terrorists to insurgents to militias, and has worked with governments, international organizations and NGOs to offer new approaches to better understand and tackle modern conflict. As a security and humanitarian consultant, Berti has designed disarmament campaigns; conducted trainings of counter-insurgency and protection of civilians; worked on violence prevention; and assisted humanitarian organizations on issues related to gaining access to war-torn areas.  She has conducted research and worked across the globe -- from Central and Latin America to the Middle East, and from the United States to Eastern Africa -- and has focused her work on some of the world's most complex conflicts, from Syria, to Iraq, to Gaza, to Burundi. 

Berti has written four books, and her writing has appeared in Foreign Policy and Foreign Affairs.

"whylisten": "

Benedetta Berti is an expert on the role of armed groups and the future of armed conflict, especially in the Middle East. She has spent over a decade researching non-state armed groups, from terrorists to insurgents to militias, and has worked with governments, international organizations and NGOs to offer new approaches to better understand and tackle modern conflict. As a security and humanitarian consultant, Berti has designed disarmament campaigns; conducted trainings of counter-insurgency and protection of civilians; worked on violence prevention; and assisted humanitarian organizations on issues related to gaining access to war-torn areas.  She has conducted research and worked across the globe -- from Central and Latin America to the Middle East, and from the United States to Eastern Africa -- and has focused her work on some of the world's most complex conflicts, from Syria, to Iraq, to Gaza, to Burundi. 

Berti has written four books, and her writing has appeared in Foreign Policy and Foreign Affairs.

author: Benedetta_Berti;
title: Did the global response to 9/11 make us safer?

aws-transcripts.transcript: almost 20 years have passed since 9 11 It is style to take stock of where we stand and stop and think it is time to ask ourselves, Have the assumptions and policies we develop in the wake of these tragic events, Truly made us more secure. Have the major societies both in Europe and they need in the United States more resilient. I've worked all my life in the field of security and defense, and I am convinced that now, more than ever, we need to radically refrain the way we think and act about security and especially about international security by international security. I actually mean what we do, how we prepare our countries to better respond and prevent external threats, and I will protect our citizens. The key to both is to focus on protecting civilians both in our own countries and in those where were present in the name of security. Now, this idea goes against the fixed narrative that we developed over the past 20 years over what security is and out gets it. But that narrative is flawed and worse. It is counterproductive. Over the past 20 years, both in the United States and New Year in Europe. We've come to accept that we must talk about security and zero some terms, as if the only way to gain more security is by compromising our values and rights, security versus human rights, safety versus freedom and development. This is a false opposition. It just doesn't work like that. We need to recognize the security and human rights are not opposite values. They are intrinsically related. After all, the most basic human rights is the right to live and to be free from violence. And the state's most basic responsibility is to guarantee that right for its citizens. Conversely, if we think about communities all over the world affected by war and conflict, it is insecurity and violence that stops them from achieving their full freedom and development. Now they need basic security just as much as we do, and they need it so they can live on not a normal life and so that they can enjoy their human rights. This is why we need a shift. We need to acknowledge the sustainable security, builds on a foundation of human rights, build some promoting and respecting human rights. Also, over the past two decades, we have accepted that the best way to guarantee our own security is by defeating our enemies. And to do that, we need to rely almost exclusively on the military again. Disclosure with my work, with my research with what I see in the field, what I see is that building sustainable security has a lot less to do with crush and enemies as a lot less to do with winning on the battlefield and has a lot more to do with protecting victims and building stability. And to do that, while the military alone is simply insufficient. This is why I believe we need to shelve the never ending war on terror, and we need to replace it with a security agenda that is driven by the principle of protecting civilians, no matter where they're from. What password, eh, old or where they live? Vancouver, New York, Kabul Most sue Aleppo or Duma. Sustainable security tells us there were more likely to have long term security at home for ourselves if we focus our engagements abroad on protecting civilians and on ensuring their lives are lived in dignity and free from violence, for example, we all know that defeating eyes is. Is the security achievement? Absolutely. But rebuilding destroyed homes, restoring order, ensure your representative political system, these air, just as if not more important, and not just for the security of civilians in Iraq and in Syria before are all security and for global stability. More fundamentally, Isis danger should not just be counted in the number of weapons it holds, but also in the number of children it has kept out of school or indoctrinated. This is from a security perspective from a security perspective, that long term generational impact over the millions of children in Syria growing up, knowing only war and out of school. This is a far more dangerous threat to stability than all of Isis weapons combined. And we should spend just as much time and just as much energy to counter this as what we spent when countering Isis find militarily. Over the past two decades, our security policy has been short term. It has focused on the here and now it has systematically downplayed the link between what we do today in the name of security and the long term impact off those choices. In the years after 9 11 some of the chore choices some of the policies we've implemented have probably made us less, not more secure in the long term, sustainable civilian center security needs to look at what happens in the long term again, for example, relying on drones to target enemies in faraway countries. Maybe a tool. It may be a tool to make sure, or to lessen the threat of an imminent attack on the United States. But what about the long term impact if civilians are killed?
